paragraph: CHAPTER 8. At the Sign of the Spy-glass
tokens: chapter sign glass

paragraph: WHEN I had done breakfasting the squire gave me a note addressed to John Silver, at the sign of the Spy-glass, and told me I should easily find the place by following the line of the docks and keeping a bright lookout for a little tavern with a large brass telescope for sign. I set off, overjoyed at this opportunity to see some more of the ships and seamen, and picked my way among a great crowd of people and carts and bales, for the dock was now at its busiest, until I found the tavern in question.
tokens: do breakfast squire give note address sign glass tell find place follow line dock keep bright lookout little tavern large brass telescope sign set overjoy opportunity see more ship seamen pick way great crowd person cart bale dock busy find tavern question

paragraph: It was a bright enough little place of entertainment. The sign was newly painted; the windows had neat red curtains; the floor was cleanly sanded. There was a street on each side and an open door on both, which made the large, low room pretty clear to see in, in spite of clouds of tobacco smoke.
tokens: bright enough little place entertainment sign paint window have neat red curtain floor sand be street side open door make large low room clear see spite cloud tobacco smoke

paragraph: The customers were mostly seafaring men, and they talked so loudly that I hung at the door, almost afraid to enter.
tokens: customer seafare man talk hang door afraid enter

paragraph: As I was waiting, a man came out of a side room, and at a glance I was sure he must be Long John. His left leg was cut off close by the hip, and under the left shoulder he carried a crutch, which he managed with wonderful dexterity, hopping about upon it like a bird. He was very tall and strong, with a face as big as a ham--plain and pale, but intelligent and smiling. Indeed, he seemed in the most cheerful spirits, whistling as he moved about among the tables, with a merry word or a slap on the shoulder for the more favoured of his guests.
tokens: wait man come side room glance sure long left leg cut hip left shoulder carry crutch manage wonderful dexterity hopping bird tall strong face big ham plain pale intelligent smile seem cheerful spirit whistle move table merry word slap shoulder favour guest

paragraph: Now, to tell you the truth, from the very first mention of Long John in Squire Trelawney's letter I had taken a fear in my mind that he might prove to be the very one-legged sailor whom I had watched for so long at the old Benbow. But one look at the man before me was enough. I had seen the captain, and Black Dog, and the blind man, Pew, and I thought I knew what a buccaneer was like--a very different creature, according to me, from this clean and pleasant-tempered landlord.
tokens: tell truth very first mention long letter take fear mind prove very legged sailor watch old look man enough see captain black blind man think know buccaneer different creature accord clean pleasant temper landlord

paragraph: I plucked up courage at once, crossed the threshold, and walked right up to the man where he stood, propped on his crutch, talking to a customer.
tokens: pluck courage cross threshold walk man stand proppe crutch talk customer

paragraph: "Mr. Silver, sir?" I asked, holding out the note.
tokens: sir ask hold note

paragraph: "Yes, my lad," said he; "such is my name, to be sure. And who may you be?" And then as he saw the squire's letter, he seemed to me to give something almost like a start.
tokens: lad say such name sure see squire letter seem give start

paragraph: "Oh!" said he, quite loud, and offering his hand. "I see. You are our new cabin-boy; pleased I am to see you."
tokens: say loud offer hand see new cabin boy pleased see

paragraph: And he took my hand in his large firm grasp.
tokens: take hand large firm grasp

paragraph: Just then one of the customers at the far side rose suddenly and made for the door. It was close by him, and he was out in the street in a moment. But his hurry had attracted my notice, and I recognized him at glance. It was the tallow-faced man, wanting two fingers, who had come first to the Admiral Benbow.
tokens: customer far side rise make door close street moment hurry attract notice recognize glance tallow face man want finger come

paragraph: "Oh," I cried, "stop him! It's Black Dog!"
tokens: cry stop black dog

paragraph: "I don't care two coppers who he is," cried Silver. "But he hasn't paid his score. Harry, run and catch him."
tokens: care copper cry pay score run catch

paragraph: One of the others who was nearest the door leaped up and started in pursuit.
tokens: other door leap start pursuit

paragraph: "If he were Admiral Hawke he shall pay his score," cried Silver; and then, relinquishing my hand, "Who did you say he was?" he asked. "Black what?"
tokens: pay score cry relinquish hand say ask black

paragraph: "Dog, sir," said I. "Has Mr. Trelawney not told you of the buccaneers? He was one of them."
tokens: dog sir say tell buccaneer

paragraph: "So?" cried Silver. "In my house! Ben, run and help Harry. One of those swabs, was he? Was that you drinking with him, Morgan? Step up here."
tokens: cry house run help swab drink step

paragraph: The man whom he called Morgan--an old, grey-haired, mahogany-faced sailor--came forward pretty sheepishly, rolling his quid.
tokens: man call old grey hair mahogany face sailor come roll quid

paragraph: "Now, Morgan," said Long John very sternly, "you never clapped your eyes on that Black--Black Dog before, did you, now?"
tokens: say clapp eye black black

paragraph: "Not I, sir," said Morgan with a salute.
tokens: sir say salute

paragraph: "You didn't know his name, did you?"
tokens: know name

paragraph: "No, sir."
tokens: sir

paragraph: "By the powers, Tom Morgan, it's as good for you!" exclaimed the landlord. "If you had been mixed up with the like of that, you would never have put another foot in my house, you may lay to that. And what was he saying to you?"
tokens: power good exclaim landlord mix like put foot house lay say

paragraph: "I don't rightly know, sir," answered Morgan.
tokens: know sir answer

paragraph: "Do you call that a head on your shoulders, or a blessed dead-eye?" cried Long John. "Don't rightly know, don't you! Perhaps you don't happen to rightly know who you was speaking to, perhaps? Come, now, what was he jawing--v'yages, cap'ns, ships? Pipe up! What was it?"
tokens: call head shoulder bless dead eye cry know happen know speak come jaw yage cap'n ship pipe

paragraph: "We was a-talkin' of keel-hauling," answered Morgan.
tokens: talkin keel hauling answer

paragraph: "Keel-hauling, was you? And a mighty suitable thing, too, and you may lay to that. Get back to your place for a lubber, Tom."
tokens: hauling mighty suitable thing lay get place lubber

paragraph: And then, as Morgan rolled back to his seat, Silver added to me in a confidential whisper that was very flattering, as I thought, "He's quite an honest man, Tom Morgan, on'y stupid. And now," he ran on again, aloud, "let's see--Black Dog? No, I don't know the name, not I. Yet I kind of think I've--yes, I've seen the swab. He used to come here with a blind beggar, he used."
tokens: roll seat add confidential whisper flattering think honest man stupid run let see black dog know name kind think see swab use come blind beggar use

paragraph: "That he did, you may be sure," said I. "I knew that blind man too. His name was Pew."
tokens: sure say know blind man name

paragraph: "It was!" cried Silver, now quite excited. "Pew! That were his name for certain. Ah, he looked a shark, he did! If we run down this Black Dog, now, there'll be news for Cap'n Trelawney! Ben's a good runner; few seamen run better than Ben. He should run him down, hand over hand, by the powers! He talked o' keel-hauling, did he? I'LL keel-haul him!"
tokens: cry excited name certain look shark run black dog be news good runner few seamen run good run hand hand power talk keel hauling keel haul

paragraph: All the time he was jerking out these phrases he was stumping up and down the tavern on his crutch, slapping tables with his hand, and giving such a show of excitement as would have convinced an Old Bailey judge or a Bow Street runner. My suspicions had been thoroughly reawakened on finding Black Dog at the Spy-glass, and I watched the cook narrowly. But he was too deep, and too ready, and too clever for me, and by the time the two men had come back out of breath and confessed that they had lost the track in a crowd, and been scolded like thieves, I would have gone bail for the innocence of Long John Silver.
tokens: time jerk phrase stump tavern crutch slap table hand give show excitement convince old judge runner suspicion reawaken find black glass watch cook deep ready clever time man come breath confess lose track crowd scold thief go bail innocence long

paragraph: "See here, now, Hawkins," said he, "here's a blessed hard thing on a man like me, now, ain't it? There's Cap'n Trelawney--what's he to think? Here I have this confounded son of a Dutchman sitting in my own house drinking of my own rum! Here you comes and tells me of it plain; and here I let him give us all the slip before my blessed deadlights! Now, Hawkins, you do me justice with the cap'n. You're a lad, you are, but you're as smart as paint. I see that when you first come in. Now, here it is: What could I do, with this old timber I hobble on? When I was an A B master mariner I'd have come up alongside of him, hand over hand, and broached him to in a brace of old shakes, I would; but now--"
tokens: see say bless hard thing man be think have confound son sit own house drinking own rum come tell plain let give slip bless deadlight do justice cap lad smart paint see come do old timber hobble a b master mariner come hand hand broach brace old shake

paragraph: And then, all of a sudden, he stopped, and his jaw dropped as though he had remembered something.
tokens: stop jaw drop remember

paragraph: "The score!" he burst out. "Three goes o' rum! Why, shiver my timbers, if I hadn't forgotten my score!"
tokens: score burst go o' rum shiver timber forget score

paragraph: And falling on a bench, he laughed until the tears ran down his cheeks. I could not help joining, and we laughed together, peal after peal, until the tavern rang again.
tokens: fall bench laugh tear run cheek help join laugh peal peal tavern ring

paragraph: "Why, what a precious old sea-calf I am!" he said at last, wiping his cheeks. "You and me should get on well, Hawkins, for I'll take my davy I should be rated ship's boy. But come now, stand by to go about. This won't do. Dooty is dooty, messmates. I'll put on my old cockerel hat, and step along of you to Cap'n Trelawney, and report this here affair. For mind you, it's serious, young Hawkins; and neither you nor me's come out of it with what I should make so bold as to call credit. Nor you neither, says you; not smart--none of the pair of us smart. But dash my buttons! That was a good un about my score."
tokens: precious old sea calf say last wipe cheek get take davy rate ship boy come stand go do dooty messmate put old cockerel hat step report affair mind serious young come make bold call credit say smart pair smart dash button good un score

paragraph: And he began to laugh again, and that so heartily, that though I did not see the joke as he did, I was again obliged to join him in his mirth.
tokens: begin laugh see joke oblige join mirth

paragraph: On our little walk along the quays, he made himself the most interesting companion, telling me about the different ships that we passed by, their rig, tonnage, and nationality, explaining the work that was going forward--how one was discharging, another taking in cargo, and a third making ready for sea--and every now and then telling me some little anecdote of ships or seamen or repeating a nautical phrase till I had learned it perfectly. I began to see that here was one of the best of possible shipmates.
tokens: little walk quay make interesting companion tell different ship pass rig tonnage nationality explain work go one discharg take cargo third make ready sea tell little anecdote ship seamen repeat nautical phrase learn begin see good possible shipmate

paragraph: When we got to the inn, the squire and Dr. Livesey were seated together, finishing a quart of ale with a toast in it, before they should go aboard the schooner on a visit of inspection.
tokens: get inn squire seat finish quart ale toast go schooner visit inspection

paragraph: Long John told the story from first to last, with a great deal of spirit and the most perfect truth. "That was how it were, now, weren't it, Hawkins?" he would say, now and again, and I could always bear him entirely out.
tokens: long tell story first last great deal spirit perfect truth say bear

paragraph: The two gentlemen regretted that Black Dog had got away, but we all agreed there was nothing to be done, and after he had been complimented, Long John took up his crutch and departed.
tokens: gentleman regret black get agree be do compliment take crutch depart

paragraph: "All hands aboard by four this afternoon," shouted the squire after him.
tokens: hand afternoon shout squire

paragraph: "Aye, aye, sir," cried the cook, in the passage.
tokens: cry cook passage

paragraph: "Well, squire," said Dr. Livesey, "I don't put much faith in your discoveries, as a general thing; but I will say this, John Silver suits me."
tokens: squire say put much faith discovery general thing say suit

paragraph: "The man's a perfect trump," declared the squire.
tokens: man perfect trump declare squire

paragraph: "And now," added the doctor, "Jim may come on board with us, may he not?"
tokens: add doctor come board

paragraph: "To be sure he may," says squire. "Take your hat, Hawkins, and we'll see the ship."
